ARTICLE.TITLE: West Midlands Police is recruiting officers now
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Want the best Coventry and Warwickshire news delivered straight to your inbox? Sign up here! Sign up here! Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Invalid Email

West Midlands Police is recruiting new officers now and is particularly targeting young people who have just received their A-level results.

The force has changed the way it recruits its officers and now has a student officer programme which offers two routes to becoming a police officer.

The scheme is open to people who have done A-levels, or an alternative level 3 course of study, and those who have already graduated.

The recruitment programme is a rolling one but the force has made a particular appeal to young people who might have just got their A-level results, in a year where the entire educational landscape has changed.

Several tweets on the force’s @JobsWMP Twitter feed have focused on A-level students.

One says: “Calling all #ALevelResults students! Got your grades? Thinking about your options? Our student officer programme could be for you. *No student fees *Salary while you train *Achieve a policing degree *Study with@StaffsUni.”

The recruitment section of the West Midlands Police website echoes the A-level appeal and says: “Exams, grades, predictions…it’s all different this year but that’s fine by us.

“Whether you’ve got what you had hoped for or have received disappointing news, there’s always options if policing is your dream.

“We hope you got what you wanted…and they might lead you into a career with us via our student officer programme.

“We are recruiting new police officers to join our training schemes.

"There’s several ways of joining, depending on whether you’ve got your A-level (or other level 3) results or maybe you’ve already been to uni and have graduated.

"We’re happy to hear from you, regardless."

Paid while on job

Outlining details of how the scheme works it adds: “And the good news is that you’ll be paid to be a student police officer while you undergo your training – and we pay for that training to be delivered in partnership with Staffordshire University so that you get a degree or graduate diploma when your probation ends and you become a fully-fledged officer.”

Highlighting what it can offer the West Midlands Police website lists the following:

* No tuition fees

* A professional qualification

* A good salary while training, which will increase every year

* A varied career when training is done

Reiterating the appeal to students who have just had their A-level results in a year where the entire education system has been hit by the coronavirus pandemic the force says: “We’re even looking at ways we can work with local colleges to offer support to students who have not got the results they need.

“But, grades aren’t everything.

“As our advertising shows, your everyday skills are as much in demand when you begin your police officer training.

“Kindness, empathy, humour, friendship, listening, showing resilience, being able to relate to people …we could go on.

“They are not skills we learn at college or university. They are just who we are.

“People want us to be professional but they need to see that we are human too, because policing is often about those simple conversations as much as it can be about chasing an offender or responding to a 999 call.”

Coventry news. Free. To your inbox You can get your Coventry and Warwickshire news straight to your email inbox - and it's FREE! All you need to do is sign up here. The emails come out twice a day, at lunchtime and in the evening, with the latest news, what's on and sport from across Coventry and Warwickshire.

The recruitment campaign slogan is ‘you’re made for this’ and the campaign is highlighting real stories of how officers have helped people and how their behaviour has made a real difference.

West Midlands Police has described its student officer programme as “the new way to become a police officer”.

The force - which covers Coventry, Birmingham, Wolverhampton, Solihull, Sandwell, Dudley and Walsall - has become one of the first to recruit student officers to study for a degree, or a graduate diploma, while they train.

West Midlands Police is offering two routes into the profession. Both involve a course of study combined with practical, on-the-job training.

The main route is for people to complete a degree as part of their training, though university graduates can also undertake a post-graduate study programme.

The pay

The roles offer a salary of £21,525 for those joining the degree programme, or £22,550 for those who already have a degree and are joining as a graduate.

The degree or graduate diploma is totally funded.

Also on offer are other benefits, staff associations, social clubs and a pension.

There are no age restrictions and anyone aged 18 and over can apply.

Urging people to consider a career in the force West Midlands Police says: “Policing the West Midlands is diverse and fast-paced.

“We’re the second biggest force in the country and we cover the UK’s second city, as well as other busy towns, cities and villages.”

It adds: “Careers with us are varied and demanding – but exciting too.

“From major incidents to community policing, every day is different and with events like Coventry City of Culture 2021 and Birmingham hosting the Commonwealth Games 2022 to prepare for, a career with WMP has lots to offer.”

The routes open to becoming a police officer are as follows:

PCDA – the student officer programme (this is the main entry route for new recruits)

DHEP – the student officer programme for people who already have a degree qualification (not specific to policing)

The student officer programme represents a new approach for West Midlands Police.

It has teamed-up with Staffordshire University to train students, while helping them to earn a degree or postgraduate qualification, which will be recognised internationally.

Formal training takes place alongside practical work in one of our many policing teams across the West Midlands.

Promoting the PCDA and DHEP schemes West Midlands Police says: “After a few weeks learning the important stuff, you’ll get your uniform, join a team, and begin three years – or two if you join on our graduate programme – of practical learning that will shape your police career.

“Most of your learning will be done digitally. You’ll log onto Staffordshire University systems and watch lectures and access learning modules from your computer, without needing to travel to campus.”

It adds: “When you’re not studying you’ll be part of our team, joining colleagues to police our local communities, responding to 999 calls on the frontline or in one of our investigations teams, helping to solve some of the most serious crimes and catch those responsible.”

People can find out more about the West Midlands Police student officer scheme, the eligibility criteria and apply to join it here.

METADATA.description: Young people who have just had their A-level results are eligible to apply
METADATA.author: Enda Mullen
